concern:
I (30M) recently re-entered college as a mature international student in a foreign country. Been here a month.

The first 2 weeks, I hung around with bunch of international students from Asia. But over time, I felt different from them (18-22 year olds) and started sitting apart from them as I couldn't relate (they only talk about study and stick to themselves, they don't integrate at all with the locals).

The local students too are mainly 18-21 years old.

Raised in several countries as a kid, I feel too Asian for the (mainly 18-21 y/old) local students, and too Westernized culturally for the international Asian students. I'm older at 30 than people in both. Other mature students? There's only 1 who talks about study all the time. Due to age and being racially different, I feel I don't fit in anywhere.

I ended up sitting in lectures alone by myself again, and have begun to feel down after a few incidents:

1. Group conversation with a few local students that made eye contact with each other but not with me. I feel they don't want to talk to me, I get quieter more withdrawn; they look less at me and talk more with themselves; I felt hurt and made an excuse to leave.
2. A classmate who's loud and swears a lot made racist comments about Indian and old white men (she's white herself); I called her out and then she started to argue with me, saying, patronizingly '*you're so pure and innocent*'. I defended myself. We met again today, talked about another topic, she wanted to argue again. My blood pressure rose again.
3. I asked a younger student a question about exam content and they were sarcastic and rude to me; '*Oh, you didn't read the online announcement...? Because it was posted there... you know*.' with an arrogant expression. Anger I really had to suppress.

When I arrived here, I was positive and social. Now; after every failed interaction/real/perceived rejection, and trying to socialize whilst focusing on the intensity of the course (studying 8 hours a day including Saturdays) I feel more weary and the people who were either rude or ignored me I feel anger towards and do not want to talk with anymore. These people are on a course with me for the next five years.

I feel on the outside looking in. I'm way older at 30 here and, as I sit on the outside of these local and international student groups in class, who talk amongst themselves, I go back home to my room alone. I play guitar alone. I feel intense sadness and frustration, like, just for one day I wish I could disappear. I've joined a few Meetup groups but they start next week.

I feel like I want to drop out of this course so I don't have to deal with this anymore. What can I do?

dialogue_total.statement: Hi there! Is there anything you'd like to talk about today? I'm here to listen and offer support.
Yes, I'd like to discuss my struggles with feeling isolated in my university environment due to cultural and age differences. It's been impacting my overall well-being and motivation to continue.

That sounds really tough. It can be difficult to feel like you fit in, especially when you feel like there are barriers like cultural and age differences. It's understandable that this would impact your well-being and motivation. Can you tell me more about what it's like for you on a day-to-day basis?

On a typical day, I go to classes feeling disconnected from my peers due to the age gap and cultural differences, which makes me sit alone and avoid interactions. This isolation leaves me feeling increasingly sad and unmotivated, affecting my daily routine and studies.

It sounds like you're experiencing a lot of loneliness and disconnection, which is taking a toll on your mental health and academic life. It's natural to feel this way when you're in an environment where you feel different from those around you. Have you tried exploring any clubs, organizations, or activities that might help you connect with people who share your interests?

I've joined a few Meetup groups that align with my interests, and they start next week, which I'm hoping will help. However, on campus, I haven't delved into clubs yet due to feeling out of place with my peers.

It's great that you've taken the initiative to join Meetup groups that align with your interests, and I hope they provide a sense of connection and belonging. It's also understandable that you might feel hesitant about joining campus clubs due to the age and cultural differences. However, it's worth noting that many clubs often have a diverse range of members, and you might find individuals who share similar interests or experiences. Have you considered reaching out to any clubs or organizations that pique your interest, even if it's just to learn more about their activities and members?

I've considered reaching out to campus clubs that interest me, like those related to music or culture, but I haven't followed through yet due to my ongoing feelings of not fitting in with the younger crowd. This hesitation stems from past experiences that make me wary of potential rejections.

It's completely understandable to feel hesitant about putting yourself out there, especially after experiencing rejection in the past. However, it's important to remember that each new situation is an opportunity to connect with others and build a sense of belonging. Is there a specific club or organization that particularly interests you, and if so, would you be open to exploring it further by attending a meeting or event?

Yes, the music club on campus particularly interests me because it aligns with my hobby of playing guitar. I'm somewhat open to attending a meeting, but my past experiences make me cautious about potential rejections from the younger members.

It's great that you've identified the music club as a potential avenue for connecting with others. While it's natural to feel cautious, attending a meeting could be a valuable opportunity to meet like-minded individuals who share your passion for music. To make it more comfortable, would you consider bringing a friend or reaching out to the club president beforehand to express your interest and ask any questions you might have?

I might consider reaching out to the club president first to ease my concerns, as it feels like a lower-pressure way to gauge the group. However, bringing a friend isn't feasible right now since I don't have close connections here yet.

It's great to see your willingness to take steps towards connecting with others. Remember that building new relationships takes time and effort, so be patient and kind to yourself throughout the process. Reaching out to the club president is an excellent first step, and it could help you feel more at ease before attending a meeting. Keep in mind that your shared interest in music can serve as a foundation for connecting with other club members, regardless of age differences. I encourage you to give it a try and see how it goes. Let's plan to follow up in a month to discuss your progress and any new challenges or successes you've experienced.

I'll take your advice and reach out to the club president to start, though I'm still cautious about age differences making it hard to connect. Thanks for the support I'll check back in a month as planned.
